Introduction

- John Donne, from Devotions Upon Emergent Occasions



AntonJarvis Â· No Man is an Island by John Donne

From https://nosweatshakespeare.com/quotes/famous/no-man-is-an-island

The words â€˜No man is an islandâ€™ were embedded in a deeply Christian sermon about how human beings are connected to each other, and how important that connection is for the wellbeing and survival of any individual. When you hear the church bell tolling for someone who has died, donâ€™t ask who it is, Donne says, just know that itâ€™s tolling for you too because you are part of the same society and the death of anyone takes a part of your own life away.

Does the Bell toll for thee?

Discussion Questions

  • So how does one scotch/stop a rumour? Can you be vaccinated against rumours? Is there a game-theoretic cost for the vaccination?
  • How does one be individual and different and still one of the gang? Is it possible to be inside and outside the group at the same time? Is it a good idea to be an insider and an outsider at the same time?
  • How do Echo Chambers work?
  • How does on think of products and ads, or policy messages? (Remember the â€œBell Bajaaoâ€ campaign?
  • There are popular and well-known phrases and memes in every language! Use them!!
  • Here is one for you: â€œLess Than Three!â€

Conclusions

  • Individual Actions Matter. Because they can be â€œreverse infectionsâ€ and be contagious, in a positive way.
  • Correlations between Individual Actions can create â€œstanding wavesâ€ or â€œechoesâ€ on the fabric of society.
    • Whatsapp â€œecho chambersâ€
    • Popularity of Memes, Songs, and Movie lines
    • Taglines from Ads, and Products ( e.g. â€œThink Differentâ€. Bah.)

  3. Thomas W. Valente.(2012). Network Interventions. Science(337) 49. Available here https://sci-hub.se/10.1126/science.1217330. The term â€œnetwork interventionsâ€ describes the process of using social network data to accelerate behavior change or improve organizational performance. In this Review, four strategies for network interventions are described, each of which has multiple tactical alternatives.

  4. Nicholas Christakis. (May 3, 2024). To exploit social contagion, tools are needed to efficiently identify individuals who are better able to initiate cascades. To be maximally useful, such tools should be deployable without having to actually map face-to-face social network interactions. https://t.co/DHCKxXeGYg. This is a paper that presents design tools that exploit the â€œFriendship Paradoxâ€ to create Social Contagion. A quick summary of the paper is available here. https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.adi5147
